body: Regarding the first question, In module, we have `mod.get_input_grads()` https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/module.py#L595-L614 .
@magic282 What's the optimizer you are using? We've fixed a bug in RMSProp and changed it to be non-centered.

During shape inference step MxNet checks for consistency in the input shapes w.r.t. batch size and requires that the outermost dimension for all the inputs must be equal to the batch_size and hence the error, because M's shape is (10,10). If M is a constant why not input it as a constant Variable initialized with the required value? Or else, simply make it (batch_size, 10, 10) and while using it for the dot product first take out one of the channels using slice_channel() and then use that symbol in the mx.symbol.dot().
@sxjscience I am using Adam.


Chinese characters are too many ，so your classes is too large and each class hasn't enough samples.




On 04/13/2017 18:19, realbns2008 wrote:

I use ssd in the example to train a model to identify the Chinese words in a picture.

encountered 2 problem:

1.Problem: During training i encountered NaN metrics for both cross-entropy loss and smooth-l1 loss.
After setting the clip_gradient parameters for optimization to 5 , the NaN metrics disappeared.
So the NaN metrics is caused by gradient explosion.

2. Problem: The cross-entropy metric never convergence！ I have 30000+ training samples. each sample has added some Chinese words generated randomly, and the location of the words are correctly provided to the model.

Can any one help me on the second problem?

.

Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
you can use [cast](http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.cast) to convert type.
Also check the parameter here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/cudnn_batch_norm-inl.h#L29-L37.

For now a workaround is to reshape the 5D data to 4D, perform the BatchNorm and then reshape back to 5D.

You may use the following code:

```
def batchnorm_5d(data, height, width, name, fix_gamma, eps, momentum):
    data = mx.symbol.reshape(data, shape=(0, 0, -1, width))

    data = BatchNorm(
        data,
        name=name,
        fix_gamma=fix_gamma,
        eps=eps,
        momentum=momentum)

    return mx.symbol.reshape(data, shape=(0, 0, -1, height, width))
```

This should be equivalent to the way cudnn performs the 5D (spatial) BatchNorm:

> CUDNN_BATCHNORM_SPATIAL: Normalization is performed over N+spatial
> dimensions. This mode is intended for use after
> convolutional layers (where spatial invariance
> is desired). In this mode bnBias, bnScale tensor
> dimensions are 1xCx1x1.

As cudnn throws `CUDNN_STATUS_BAD_PARAM` if:

> bnScaleBiasMeanVarDesc dimensions are not
> 1xC(x1)x1x1 for spatial or 1xC(xD)xHxW for
> per-activation mode (parenthesis for 5D).

(See the user manual at https://developer.nvidia.com/cudnn )
I'm also looking forward to an implementation.

this is the output according to `top`

note my setting is `export OMP_NUM_THREADS=8`
when running one process
```
  PID USER      PR  NI  VIRT  RES  SHR S %CPU %MEM    TIME+  COMMAND                                                                                       
55539 fchua     20   0 2119m 982m  17m S 805.7  1.5   1262:32 python     
```
but when running two separate process

```
  PID USER      PR  NI  VIRT  RES  SHR S %CPU %MEM    TIME+  COMMAND                                                                                       
 1656 fchua     20   0 2460m 1.3g  17m S 403.2  2.0   1:00.52 python                                                                                        
55539 fchua     20   0 2119m 982m  17m S 402.8  1.5   1241:20 python  
```
notice how the %CPU drop from 800% to 400% for each process, this indicates they are sharing 1 physical CPU instead of utilizing the other.

I wonder does it has anything to do with `KMP_AFFINITY=granularity=fine,compact,1,0` according to this page [performance](http://mxnet.io/how_to/perf.html)

I think there are two types of "understanding" you may want to accommodate:
1) How to use the API. For this you need the example to be as simple as
possible (even if it doesn't make much sense in terms of complexity vs
accuracy, as in the example in this pr)
2) How to effectively use STNs: For this, sure, you may want to change the
localisation network, but most important you'll need another dataset
(vanilla mnist is too easy) .

@piiswrong
Would it cost too much memory if we choose to manually compute the second-oder derivative?
It is usually fine as long as the objective is an scalar . You don't really need hessian, but functions of gradient

i noticed that `OMP_NUM_THREADS=8, MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS=1` is equivalent to
`OMP_NUM_THREADS=4, MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS=2` in terms of CPU usage, I wonder which configuration should I use?
It doesn't matter. When compiling with mxnet nnvm will use mxnet/dmlc-core
ok. LGTM

Hi @szha,

I pip installed mxnet and ran some basic training scripts from tests/python/train. On AWS's P2 instances it worked just fine. On G2.2xlarge instance I got "Illegal instruction":

`

@bhokaal2k Got it. Thanks

Since MXNet uses Zeromq libary in ps-lite for inter-node communication, personally I don't think RDMA is supported yet. The only RDMA-related discussion on Zeromq dated back to 2011.

https://lists.zeromq.org/pipermail/zeromq-dev/2011-December/014502.html

In that replied, Gabriele pointed out some misconceptions on RDMA, RoCE and IB verbs. His dissatisfactory  on the performance of SDP (an alternative way to use the RDMA-enable network adapters), is described briefly. 

http://zeromq.org/results:ib-tests-v206
http://mvapich.cse.ohio-state.edu/performance/pt_to_pt/

Comparing the performance numbers in the links above is unfair. Both hardware and software environemtn on the zmq platform is outdated while MVAPICH2 runs on the latest device. However, the numbers still reveal the current status of RDMA on these two libs:

1.  ~0.8million msg/s 888MB/s throughput 36mus latency @4kB for zmq;
2. ~2million msg/s 2GB/s throughput < 2mus latency @4kB for MVAPICH2. 

But better performance does NOT necessarily mean better choice. I think MXNet team make tradeoffs between many aspects. I appreciate if they can share their experiences on this design choice.

It is because Speedometer callback reset eval metric currently. In case you use a list of callbacks you can fix this by putting Speedometer at the end of the list (it would be fixed with this pr https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5827).

Hi, I meet the same problem and have no idea on how to fix it. Excuse me, how do you "specify the shape of label"?

One important reason seems to me that documentation is not available or out-dated.

For instance the info on C++ API on mxnet,io can be considered as obsolete. The older version of this API had at least a VS solution and a complete set of header files so you can see how to build a working sample. On the latest version of the C++ API there is no VS solution anymore so you have to find out everything by trial and error (oruse the old version and copy relevant settings).

For us, users, it is kind of free so I do not like to complain. But if there is time and/or budget for the maintainers, some more up-to-date and less cryptic documentation would at least attract more people from SME's. It is for me hard to defend it took weeks to get a bare working MxNet with C++ interface on a Win10 system with a Titan X Board .

@piiswrong. I'm afraid this is a bug.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/dev/python/mxnet/image.py#L26
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/dev/src/io/image_io.cc#L94

In function Imdecode, when param.flag = 0, cv::imdecode loads a grayscale image. However following color conversion code 

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/dev/src/io/image_io.cc#L127
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/dev/src/io/image_io.cc#L150

didn't check this flag and calls cv::cvtColor on a CV_8UC1 image, which triggers assertion 
> OpenCV Error: Assertion failed (scn == 3 || scn == 4) in cv::ipp_cvtColor

@poorfriend You may pass to_rgb=0 to imdecode when loading grayscale image to skip this conversion.

@benqua  you can refer to the MnistMlp example: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/scala-package/examples/src/main/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnetexamples/module/MnistMlp.scala#L43
I think the 'runIntermediateLevelApi' function shows how to get the value of EvalMetric after each epoch.

Use two separate modules with fixed random seeds to train two different models starting with the exact same weights, same training data sequence(obtained by switching off shuffling in dataIter or possibly by seeding with the same seed), same number of epochs and then compare the two, if it is the comparison you are after?

I guess this is just a convention coming from the statistical pattern recognition domain where the rows of the weight matrix are treated as the basis vectors of the subspace spanned by W and the multiplication from the left is considered as projecting in that subspace. Anyways, it should not matter this is just a convention being followed by MxNet see here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/fully_connected-inl.h#L81

The `libopenblas.so` in the package `libopenblas-dev` in Ubuntu 14.04 didn't include the LAPACK routines that the code links to, I had to change the CI Docker base image to Ubuntu 16.04 to correct the problem. An ensuing problem was that the Ubuntu 16.04 Docker image only includes a minimal list of packages and doesn't include `sudo`, so I had to comment out `sudo` in the CI build script.
